an3.31:1.1.pli: “Sabrahmakāni, bhikkhave, tāni kulāni yesaṃ puttānaṃ mātāpitaro ajjhāgāre pūjitā honti.
an3.31:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a family where the children honor their parents in their home is said to live with divinity.

an3.31:1.2.pli: Sapubbācariyakāni, bhikkhave, tāni kulāni yesaṃ puttānaṃ mātāpitaro ajjhāgāre pūjitā honti.
an3.31:1.2.eng: A family where the children honor their parents in their home is said to live with the first tutors.

an3.31:1.3.pli: Sāhuneyyāni, bhikkhave, tāni kulāni yesaṃ puttānaṃ mātāpitaro ajjhāgāre pūjitā honti.
an3.31:1.3.eng: A family where the children honor their parents in their home is said to live with those worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods.

an3.31:1.4.eng: ‘Divinity’ is a term for your parents.

an3.31:1.5.eng: ‘First tutors’ is a term for your parents.

an3.31:1.6.eng: ‘Worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods’ is a term for your parents.

an3.31:1.8.pli: Bahukārā, bhikkhave, mātāpitaro puttānaṃ, āpādakā posakā, imassa lokassa dassetāroti.
an3.31:1.8.eng: Parents are very helpful to their children, they raise them, nurture them, and show them the world.

an3.31:2.3.eng: They’re worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods <j>from their children,

an3.31:3.2.eng: would revere them and honor them

an3.31:4.3.eng: in this life they’re praised by the astute,

an3.31:4.4.eng: and they depart to rejoice in heaven.”

an3.32:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.32:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:

an3.32:2.1.pli: “Siyā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā nāssu, bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā nāssu;
an3.32:2.1.eng: “Could it be, sir, that a mendicant might gain a state of immersion such that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body; and no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for externally for all signs;

an3.32:2.2.pli: yañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ upasampajja viharato ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na honti tañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ upasampajja vihareyyā”ti?
an3.32:2.2.eng: and that they’d live having attained the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where I-making, mine-making, and the underlying tendency to conceit are no more?”

an3.32:2.3.pli: “Siyā, ānanda, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā nāssu, bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā nāssu;
an3.32:2.3.eng: “It could be, Ānanda, that a mendicant gains a state of immersion such that they have no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body; and no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for externally for all signs;

an3.32:2.4.pli: yañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ upasampajja viharato ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na honti tañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ upasampajja vihareyyā”ti.
an3.32:2.4.eng: and that they’d live having attained the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where I-making, mine-making, and the underlying tendency to conceit are no more.”

an3.32:3.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana, bhante, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā nāssu, bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā nāssu;

an3.32:3.2.pli: yañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ upasampajja viharato ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na honti tañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ upasampajja vihareyyā”ti?

an3.32:4.2.pli: ‘etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
an3.32:4.2.eng: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.’

an3.32:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā nāssu, bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā nāssu;
an3.32:4.3.eng: That’s how, Ānanda, a mendicant might gain a state of immersion such that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body; and no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for externally for all signs;

an3.32:4.4.pli: yañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ upasampajja viharato ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na honti tañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ upasampajja vihareyyāti.
an3.32:4.4.eng: and that they’d live having achieved the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where I-making, mine-making, and the underlying tendency to conceit are no more.

an3.32:5.1.pli: Idañca pana metaṃ, ānanda, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ pārāyane puṇṇakapañhe:
an3.32:5.1.eng: And Ānanda, this is what I was referring to in ‘The Way to the Far Shore’, in ‘The Questions of Puṇṇaka’ when I said:

an3.32:6.1.eng: ‘Having appraised the world high and low,

an3.32:6.2.eng: there is nothing in the world that disturbs them.

an3.32:6.3.eng: Peaceful, unclouded, untroubled, <j>with no need for hope—

an3.32:6.4.eng: they’ve crossed over rebirth and old age, I declare.’”

an3.33:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an3.33:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Sāriputta went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

an3.33:1.3.pli: vitthārenapi kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ;

an3.33:1.4.pli: saṅkhittavitthārenapi kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ;
an3.33:1.4.eng: maybe both in brief and in detail.

an3.33:1.5.eng: But it’s hard to find anyone who understands.”

an3.33:1.6.eng: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

an3.33:1.7.pli: yaṃ bhagavā saṅkhittenapi dhammaṃ deseyya, vitthārenapi dhammaṃ deseyya, saṅkhittavitthārenapi dhammaṃ deseyya.
an3.33:1.7.eng: Let the Buddha teach Dhamma in brief, in detail, and both in brief and in detail.

an3.33:1.8.eng: There will be those who understand the teaching!”

an3.33:2.1.eng: “So, Sāriputta, you should train like this:

an3.33:2.2.pli: ‘imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na bhavissanti, bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na bhavissanti, yañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ upasampajja viharato ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na honti tañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ upasampajja viharissāmā’ti.
an3.33:2.2.eng: ‘There’ll be no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body; and no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit externally for all signs; and we’ll live having achieved the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where I-making, mine-making, and the underlying tendency to conceit are no more.’

an3.33:3.1.pli: Yato ca kho, sāriputta, bhikkhuno imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na honti, bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na honti, yañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ upasampajja viharato ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na honti tañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ upasampajja viharati;
an3.33:3.1.eng: When a mendicant has no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body; and no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit externally for all signs; and they live having attained the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where I-making, mine-making, and the underlying tendency to conceit are no more—

an3.33:3.3.pli: ‘bhikkhu acchecchi taṇhaṃ, vivattayi saṃyojanaṃ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassa’.
an3.33:3.3.eng: a mendicant who has cut off craving, cast off the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.

an3.33:3.4.pli: Idañca pana metaṃ, sāriputta, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ pārāyane udayapañhe:
an3.33:3.4.eng: And Sāriputta, this is what I was referring to in ‘The Way to the Far Shore’, in ‘The Questions of Udaya’ when I said:

an3.33:5.3.eng: this, I declare, is liberation by enlightenment,

an3.34:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these three sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.34:1.3.pli: Lobho nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāya, doso nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāya, moho nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāya.
an3.34:1.3.eng: Greed, hate, and delusion are sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.34:2.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, lobhapakataṃ kammaṃ lobhajaṃ lobhanidānaṃ lobhasamudayaṃ, yatthassa attabhāvo nibbattati tattha taṃ kammaṃ vipaccati.
an3.34:2.1.eng: Any deed that emerges from greed—born, sourced, and originated from greed—ripens where that new incarnation is born.

an3.34:2.2.pli: Yattha taṃ kammaṃ vipaccati tattha tassa kammassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti, diṭṭhe vā dhamme upapajja vā apare vā pariyāye.
an3.34:2.2.eng: And wherever that deed ripens, its result is experienced—either in the present life, or in the next life, or in some subsequent period.

an3.34:3.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, dosapakataṃ kammaṃ dosajaṃ dosanidānaṃ dosasamudayaṃ, yatthassa attabhāvo nibbattati tattha taṃ kammaṃ vipaccati.
an3.34:3.1.eng: Any deed that emerges from hate—born, sourced, and originated from hate—ripens where that new incarnation is born.

an3.34:3.2.pli: Yattha taṃ kammaṃ vipaccati tattha tassa kammassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti, diṭṭhe vā dhamme upapajja vā apare vā pariyāye.
an3.34:3.2.eng: And wherever that deed ripens, its result is experienced—either in the present life, or in the next life, or in some subsequent period.

an3.34:4.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, mohapakataṃ kammaṃ mohajaṃ mohanidānaṃ mohasamudayaṃ, yatthassa attabhāvo nibbattati tattha taṃ kammaṃ vipaccati.
an3.34:4.1.eng: Any deed that emerges from delusion—born, sourced, and originated from delusion—ripens where that new incarnation is born.

an3.34:4.2.pli: Yattha taṃ kammaṃ vipaccati tattha tassa kammassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti, diṭṭhe vā dhamme upapajja vā apare vā pariyāye.
an3.34:4.2.eng: And wherever that deed ripens, its result is experienced—either in the present life, or in the next life, or in some subsequent period.

an3.34:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, bījāni akhaṇḍāni apūtīni avātātapahatāni sārādāni sukhasayitāni sukhette suparikammakatāya bhūmiyā nikkhittāni.
an3.34:5.1.eng: Suppose some seeds were intact, unspoiled, not weather-damaged, fertile, and well-kept. They’re sown in a well-prepared, productive field,

an3.34:5.2.eng: and the heavens provide plenty of rain.

an3.34:5.3.pli: Evassu tāni, bhikkhave, bījāni vuddhiṃ viruḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjeyyuṃ.
an3.34:5.3.eng: Then those seeds would grow, increase, and mature.

an3.34:5.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yaṃ lobhapakataṃ kammaṃ lobhajaṃ lobhanidānaṃ lobhasamudayaṃ, yatthassa attabhāvo nibbattati tattha taṃ kammaṃ vipaccati.
an3.34:5.4.eng: In the same way, any deed that emerges from greed—born, sourced, and originated from greed—ripens where that new incarnation is born.

an3.34:5.5.pli: Yattha taṃ kammaṃ vipaccati tattha tassa kammassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti, diṭṭhe vā dhamme upapajja vā apare vā pariyāye.
an3.34:5.5.eng: And wherever that deed ripens, its result is experienced—either in the present life, or in the next life, or in some subsequent period.

an3.34:6.1.eng: Any deed that emerges from hate …

an3.34:6.2.pli: yaṃ mohapakataṃ kammaṃ mohajaṃ mohanidānaṃ mohasamudayaṃ, yatthassa attabhāvo nibbattati tattha taṃ kammaṃ vipaccati.
an3.34:6.2.eng: Any deed that emerges from delusion—born, sourced, and originated from delusion—ripens where that new incarnation is born.

an3.34:6.3.pli: Yattha taṃ kammaṃ vipaccati tattha tassa kammassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti, diṭṭhe vā dhamme upapajja vā apare vā pariyāye.
an3.34:6.3.eng: And wherever that deed ripens, its result is experienced—either in the present life, or in the next life, or in some subsequent period.

an3.34:6.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi nidānāni kammānaṃ samudayāya.
an3.34:6.4.eng: These are three sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.34:7.1.eng: Mendicants, there are these three sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.34:7.3.pli: Alobho nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāya, adoso nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāya, amoho nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāya.
an3.34:7.3.eng: Contentment, love, and understanding are sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.34:8.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, alobhapakataṃ kammaṃ alobhajaṃ alobhanidānaṃ alobhasamudayaṃ, lobhe vigate evaṃ taṃ kammaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.
an3.34:8.1.eng: Any deed that emerges from contentment—born, sourced, and originated from contentment—is given up when greed is done away with. It’s cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

an3.34:9.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, adosapakataṃ kammaṃ adosajaṃ adosanidānaṃ adosasamudayaṃ, dose vigate evaṃ taṃ kammaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.
an3.34:9.1.eng: Any deed that emerges from love—born, sourced, and originated from love—is abandoned when hate is done away with. It’s cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

an3.34:10.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, amohapakataṃ kammaṃ amohajaṃ amohanidānaṃ amohasamudayaṃ, mohe vigate evaṃ taṃ kammaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.
an3.34:10.1.eng: Any deed that emerges from understanding—born, sourced, and originated from understanding—is abandoned when delusion is done away with. It’s cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

an3.34:11.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, bījāni akhaṇḍāni apūtīni avātātapahatāni sārādāni sukhasayitāni.
an3.34:11.1.eng: Suppose some seeds were intact, unspoiled, not damaged by wind and sun, fertile, and well-kept.

an3.34:11.2.eng: But someone would burn them with fire,

an3.34:11.4.pli: Masiṃ karitvā mahāvāte vā ophuṇeyya nadiyā vā sīghasotāya pavāheyya.
an3.34:11.4.eng: and whisk away the ashes in a strong wind, or glide them down a swift stream.

an3.34:11.5.pli: Evassu tāni, bhikkhave, bījāni ucchinnamūlāni tālāvatthukatāni anabhāvaṅkatāni āyatiṃ anuppādadhammāni.
an3.34:11.5.eng: Then those seeds would be cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

an3.34:11.6.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yaṃ alobhapakataṃ kammaṃ alobhajaṃ alobhanidānaṃ alobhasamudayaṃ, lobhe vigate evaṃ taṃ kammaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.
an3.34:11.6.eng: In the same way, any deed that emerges from contentment—born, sourced, and originated from contentment—is abandoned when greed is done away with. It’s cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

an3.34:12.1.eng: Any deed that emerges from love …

an3.34:12.2.pli: yaṃ amohapakataṃ kammaṃ amohajaṃ amohanidānaṃ amohasamudayaṃ, mohe vigate evaṃ taṃ kammaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti …pe…
an3.34:12.2.eng: Any deed that emerges from understanding—born, sourced, and originated from understanding—is abandoned when delusion is done away with.

an3.34:12.3.eng: It’s cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

an3.34:12.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi nidānāni kammānaṃ samudayāyāti.
an3.34:12.4.eng: These are three sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.34:13.2.eng: out of greed, hate, or delusion,

an3.34:13.5.eng: are to be experienced right here,

an3.34:14.3.eng: of the outcome of greed, hate, and delusion,

an3.35:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā āḷaviyaṃ viharati gomagge siṃsapāvane paṇṇasanthare.
an3.35:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Āḷavī, on a mat of leaves by a cow-path in a grove of Indian Rosewood.

an3.35:1.3.pli: Atha kho hatthako āḷavako jaṅghāvihāraṃ anucaṅkamamāno anuvicaramāno addasa bhagavantaṃ gomagge siṃsapāvane paṇṇasanthare nisinnaṃ.
an3.35:1.3.eng: Then as Hatthaka of Āḷavī was going for a walk he saw the Buddha sitting on that mat of leaves.

an3.35:1.4.pli: Disvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho hatthako āḷavako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.35:1.4.eng: He went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said,

an3.35:1.5.eng: “Sir, I trust the Buddha slept well?”

an3.35:1.7.pli: Ye ca pana loke sukhaṃ senti, ahaṃ tesaṃ aññataro”ti.
an3.35:1.7.eng: I am one of those who sleep at ease in the world.”

an3.35:2.1.pli: “Sītā, bhante, hemantikā ratti, antaraṭṭhako himapātasamayo, kharā gokaṇṭakahatā bhūmi, tanuko paṇṇasantharo, viraḷāni rukkhassa pattāni, sītāni kāsāyāni vatthāni, sīto ca verambho vāto vāyati.
an3.35:2.1.eng: “The winter nights are cold, sir, and it’s the week of mid-winter, when the snow falls. Rough is the ground trampled under the cows’ hooves, and thin is the mat of leaves. The leaves are sparse on the trees, the ocher robes are cold, and cold blows the north wind.

an3.35:2.4.pli: Ye ca pana loke sukhaṃ senti, ahaṃ tesaṃ aññataro’”ti.
an3.35:2.4.eng: I am one of those who sleep at ease in the world.’”

an3.35:3.1.pli: “Tena hi, kumāra, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
an3.35:3.1.eng: “Well then, prince, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

an3.35:3.2.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, kumāra, idhassa gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā kūṭāgāraṃ ullittāvalittaṃ nivātaṃ phusitaggaḷaṃ pihitavātapānaṃ.
an3.35:3.2.eng: What do you think? Take the case of a householder or his son, who lives in a bungalow, plastered inside and out, draft-free, with door fastened and window shuttered.

an3.35:3.3.pli: Tatrassa pallaṅko gonakatthato paṭikatthato paṭalikatthato kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇo sauttaracchado ubhato lohitakūpadhāno;
an3.35:3.3.eng: His couch is spread with woolen covers—shag-piled, pure white, or embroidered with flowers—and spread with a fine deer hide. It has a canopy above and red pillows at both ends.

an3.35:3.4.eng: An oil lamp is burning there,

an3.35:3.5.pli: catasso ca pajāpatiyo manāpāmanāpena paccupaṭṭhitā assu.
an3.35:3.5.eng: while his four wives attend to him in all manner of agreeable ways.

an3.35:3.6.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, kumāra, sukhaṃ vā so sayeyya no vā?
an3.35:3.6.eng: What do you think, prince, would he sleep at ease, or not?

an3.35:3.7.eng: Or how do you see this?”

an3.35:3.9.pli: Ye ca pana loke sukhaṃ senti, so tesaṃ aññataro”ti.
an3.35:3.9.eng: Of those who sleep at ease in the world, he would be one.”

an3.35:4.2.pli: api nu tassa gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā uppajjeyyuṃ rāgajā pariḷāhā kāyikā vā cetasikā vā yehi so rāgajehi pariḷāhehi pariḍayhamāno dukkhaṃ sayeyyā”ti?
an3.35:4.2.eng: Is it not possible that a fever born of greed—physical or mental—might arise in that householder or householder’s son, burning him so he sleeps badly?”

an3.35:5.1.pli: “Yehi kho so, kumāra, gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā rāgajehi pariḷāhehi pariḍayhamāno dukkhaṃ sayeyya, so rāgo tathāgatassa pahīno ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.
an3.35:5.1.eng: “The greed that burns that householder or householder’s son, making them sleep badly, has been cut off at the root by the Realized One, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

an3.35:5.2.eng: That’s why I sleep at ease.

an3.35:6.2.pli: api nu tassa gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā uppajjeyyuṃ dosajā pariḷāhā …pe…
an3.35:6.2.eng: Is it not possible that a fever born of hate …

an3.35:6.3.pli: mohajā pariḷāhā kāyikā vā cetasikā vā yehi so mohajehi pariḷāhehi pariḍayhamāno dukkhaṃ sayeyyā”ti?
an3.35:6.3.eng: or a fever born of delusion—physical or mental—might arise in that householder or householder’s son, burning him so he sleeps badly?”

an3.35:7.1.pli: “Ye hi kho so, kumāra, gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā mohajehi pariḷāhehi pariḍayhamāno dukkhaṃ sayeyya, so moho tathāgatassa pahīno ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.
an3.35:7.1.eng: “The delusion that burns that householder or householder’s son, making them sleep badly, has been cut off at the root by the Realized One, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

an3.35:7.2.eng: That’s why I sleep at ease.
